questions.prompt: Which computer part is often called the 'brain' because it runs instructions?
questions.explanation: The CPU (central processing unit) executes instructions and coordinates what the computer does.

questions.prompt: Which type of storage keeps your files even after you shut the computer down?
questions.explanation: RAM and caches are temporary. SSD/HDD storage is meant to keep data when the power is off.

questions.prompt: What is the main job of an operating system (OS) like Windows or macOS?
choices: Manage hardware and let apps run
questions.explanation: An OS helps your computer hardware and software work together and provides the basics apps need to run.

questions.prompt: How many bits are in one byte?
questions.explanation: A byte is 8 bits. It's a common building block for measuring file sizes and memory.

questions.prompt: In programming, what is a variable best described as?
choices: A named place to store a value
questions.explanation: A variable is like a labeled box: you can put a value in it and reuse or change it later.

questions.prompt: What does a loop do in code?
questions.explanation: Loops repeat a set of steps until a condition is met (or for a certain number of times).

questions.prompt: At Neumont, BSCS is short for which bachelor program name?
choices: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
Bachelor of Science in Software Engineering
Bachelor of Science in Information Systems & Cybersecurity
Bachelor of Science in Software & Game Development
questions.explanation: BSCS is the common abbreviation for Bachelor of Science in Computer Science.

questions.prompt: At Neumont, BSSE is short for which bachelor program name?
choices: Bachelor of Science in Software Engineering
Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
Bachelor of Science in Information Systems & Cybersecurity
Bachelor of Science in Software & Game Development
questions.explanation: BSSE is the abbreviation for Bachelor of Science in Software Engineering.

questions.prompt: What does HTML mainly do on a webpage?
questions.explanation: HTML provides the structure of a page: headings, paragraphs, links, images, and more.

questions.prompt: What is CSS mainly used for on a webpage?
questions.explanation: CSS controls how a page looks: colors, spacing, fonts, and layout.

questions.prompt: What is JavaScript commonly used for on a website?
choices: Making the page interactive (buttons, menus, logic)
questions.explanation: JavaScript adds behavior and interactivity, like form checks, animations, and dynamic updates.

questions.prompt: In many tech programs, what does 'capstone' usually mean?
choices: A final, wrap-up project that shows what you learned
A short pop quiz every day
questions.explanation: A capstone is typically a culminating project where you apply skills from multiple classes.

questions.prompt: In a school setting, an 'enterprise project' is usually closest to what?
choices: A team project that feels like real workplace work
A new phone plan for students
A way to format your hard drive
questions.explanation: Enterprise-style projects often focus on teamwork, planning, and building something like a real product.

questions.prompt: What is a unit test?
choices: A test of your Wi-Fi speed
A small test that checks one piece of code
A final exam for a whole semester
questions.explanation: Unit tests check small parts of a program (like a function) so you can catch mistakes early.

questions.prompt: At Neumont, BSIS is short for which bachelor program name?
choices: Bachelor of Science in Information Systems & Cybersecurity
Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
Bachelor of Science in Software Engineering
Bachelor of Science in Software & Game Development
questions.explanation: BSIS refers to Information Systems & Cybersecurity.

questions.prompt: What is 'phishing'?
choices: A trick message that tries to steal your info
A fast way to download games
A bug that only happens on Mondays
questions.explanation: Phishing tries to get you to click a bad link or share passwords, codes, or personal info.

questions.prompt: What does 2FA (two-factor authentication) add on top of a password?
choices: A second proof step like a code or app prompt
questions.explanation: 2FA makes it harder for someone to log in even if they learn your password.

questions.prompt: When a site uses HTTPS, what does that usually mean for your connection?
choices: Your connection is encrypted in transit
Your password is shown in plain text
questions.explanation: HTTPS encrypts data between your browser and the website, which helps protect it while it travels.

questions.prompt: The security idea 'least privilege' is best explained as:
choices: Give everyone admin access to save time
Only give the minimum access needed to do the job
questions.explanation: Least privilege limits damage: if an account is misused, it can only do a small set of actions.

questions.prompt: Why do many systems store passwords using a one-way 'hash' instead of saving the real password?
choices: So the password can be easily recovered later
Because hashes are a one-way fingerprint, not the original text
To share passwords with other websites
questions.explanation: A hash is designed to be one-way. If a database leaks, attackers don't automatically get everyone's actual passwords.

questions.prompt: At Neumont, BSGD is short for which bachelor program name?
choices: Bachelor of Science in Software & Game Development
Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
Bachelor of Science in Software Engineering
Bachelor of Science in Information Systems & Cybersecurity
questions.explanation: BSGD is the abbreviation for Bachelor of Science in Software & Game Development.

questions.prompt: In games, what does FPS usually stand for?
questions.explanation: Frames per second is how many images are drawn each second. Higher FPS can feel smoother.

questions.prompt: In online games, 'ping' is closest to:
choices: How long data takes to travel to the server and back
How many players are on your team
How much storage your PC has
questions.explanation: Ping (latency) measures delay. Lower ping usually means your actions feel more responsive.

questions.prompt: In 2D games, a 'sprite' is usually:
choices: A small image used for a character or object
questions.explanation: Sprites are 2D images that represent characters, items, or effects on screen.

questions.prompt: Which description best matches a simple 'game loop'?
choices: Save the game once and stop
Repeat: read input -> update game state -> draw the frame
Turn off the monitor to improve FPS
questions.explanation: Most games repeatedly handle input, update what's happening, and render frames many times per second.

questions.prompt: What is a game engine (like Unity or Unreal) mainly used for?
choices: A toolset to help build games (graphics, input, physics, etc.)
questions.explanation: Game engines provide building blocks so you can focus on the game instead of starting from zero.

questions.prompt: At a high level, what's a common difference between 2D and 3D games?
choices: 2D is always online; 3D is always offline
questions.explanation: 2D is usually described with two directions (x and y). 3D adds a third direction (z) for depth.

questions.prompt: At Neumont, BSAAI is short for which bachelor program name?
choices: Bachelor of Science in Applied Artificial Intelligence and Data Engineering
Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence Engineering
Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
Bachelor of Science in Software Engineering
questions.explanation: BSAAI refers to Applied Artificial Intelligence and Data Engineering.

questions.prompt: What is a database used for?
choices: Storing and organizing information so it can be searched and updated
questions.explanation: Databases store structured information (like accounts or orders) so apps can find and change it reliably.

questions.prompt: A CSV file is best described as:
choices: A spreadsheet-like text file with values separated by commas
questions.explanation: CSV (comma-separated values) is a simple way to store rows and columns using plain text.

questions.prompt: What does 'data cleaning' usually mean?
choices: Fixing messy data (missing values, duplicates, wrong formats)
Making data look prettier with colors
questions.explanation: Clean data is easier to analyze and less likely to produce confusing or wrong results.

questions.prompt: If you're predicting the price of a house, which is an example of a 'feature'?
questions.explanation: A feature is an input piece of information the model can use to make a prediction.

questions.prompt: Which is the best example of structured data?
choices: A spreadsheet of student names and IDs
questions.explanation: Structured data fits neatly into rows and columns with consistent fields, like a table.

questions.prompt: At Neumont, BSAIE is short for which bachelor program name?
choices: Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence Engineering
Bachelor of Science in Applied Artificial Intelligence and Data Engineering
Bachelor of Science in Information Systems & Cybersecurity
Bachelor of Science in Software & Game Development
questions.explanation: BSAIE refers to Artificial Intelligence Engineering.

questions.prompt: At a high level, what is an AI model?
choices: A set of learned patterns that can make predictions or generate outputs
questions.explanation: An AI model is trained on data so it can produce outputs like classifications, predictions, or text.

questions.prompt: Which pairing best matches 'training' vs 'inference' in AI?
choices: Training: using a keyboard; Inference: using a mouse
Training: learning from data; Inference: using what was learned to make an output
Training: installing software; Inference: uninstalling software
Training: turning on Wi-Fi; Inference: turning it off
questions.explanation: Training is when the model learns from examples. Inference is when the trained model produces an output.

questions.prompt: Why do GPUs often help with AI and graphics workloads?
choices: They are better at doing many similar calculations at once
questions.explanation: GPUs are built for lots of parallel work, which is common in graphics and many AI computations.

questions.prompt: What is 'overfitting' in machine learning?
choices: When a model learns the training examples too specifically and does poorly on new data
When code is too short to run
When a dataset has too many columns
questions.explanation: Overfitting is like memorizing practice questions instead of learning the concept - great on training data, weaker on new cases.

questions.prompt: In an AI chat tool, what is a 'prompt'?
choices: The instruction or question you give the AI
questions.explanation: Your prompt is the input text that tells the AI what you want.

questions.prompt: Which habit is a good way to use AI tools responsibly?
choices: Assume the AI is always correct
Verify important facts with reliable sources
Share private passwords to get better answers
Skip reading the output and submit it
questions.explanation: AI can make mistakes, so double-check important details - especially for school, work, or safety.

questions.prompt: Which are good password habits? (Select all that apply)
choices: Reuse the same password on every site
Share your password in chat to save time
questions.explanation: Long, unique passwords plus a password manager and 2FA make accounts much harder to take over.

questions.prompt: Which are common phishing red flags? (Select all that apply)
choices: A message creates urgency like 'act now!'
The sender address looks slightly wrong
It asks for a password or a 2FA code
It links to a domain you weren't expecting
It includes your first name correctly
questions.explanation: Phishing often uses urgency and odd links/senders to trick you into giving up info or clicking something unsafe.

questions.prompt: What can version control (like Git) help with? (Select all that apply)
choices: Track changes to code over time
Work with teammates without emailing files back and forth
See who changed what and when
questions.explanation: Version control keeps a history of changes and supports teamwork, but it doesn't magically fix bugs.

questions.prompt: Which steps are part of a typical Git workflow? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: A common flow is edit -> commit -> push, and pull to get other people's changes.

questions.prompt: Which changes can often improve game performance on a PC? (Select all that apply)
choices: Open more browser tabs while playing
questions.explanation: Lower settings/resolution and closing background apps reduce workload. Restarting can clear issues that build up over time.

questions.prompt: Which are common ways games receive player input? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Games typically listen to device input (keyboard, mouse, controller, touch), not things like temperature.

questions.prompt: Which are examples of data formats you might store or send? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: CSV/JSON are common for structured data, and PNG/MP3 are common media file formats. RAM is memory, not a file format.

questions.prompt: Which issues can hurt data quality for analysis or AI? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Duplicates, missing info, inconsistent units, and messy labels can confuse analysis and lead to bad results.

questions.prompt: Which statements about AI outputs are generally true? (Select all that apply)
choices: AI can make mistakes or 'hallucinate' details
AI always knows the latest news without checking sources
AI output can reflect patterns in its training data
AI should be double-checked for high-stakes info
AI is the same as Wi-Fi
questions.explanation: AI is useful but not perfect. It's best to verify important information and remember it's shaped by data it learned from.

questions.prompt: Which are input devices (things you use to send information to the computer)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Input devices send data in (keys, clicks, sound, video). A monitor mainly outputs visuals.

questions.prompt: What does CPU stand for?
questions.explanation: CPU stands for Central Processing Unit - the part that runs instructions.

questions.prompt: What does RAM stand for?
questions.explanation: RAM is Random Access Memory - fast, temporary working memory for what you're doing right now.

questions.prompt: In Git, what command word is used to send your local commits to a remote repository?
questions.explanation: You 'push' to upload your commits to the remote (like on GitHub).

questions.prompt: What does 2FA stand for?
questions.explanation: 2FA means Two-Factor Authentication - using a second proof step in addition to a password.

questions.prompt: What does DNS stand for?
questions.explanation: DNS is the Domain Name System. It helps turn names like example.com into the numeric addresses computers use.

questions.prompt: What does FPS stand for in gaming?
questions.explanation: FPS means Frames Per Second - how many frames are drawn each second.

questions.prompt: What does CSV stand for?
questions.explanation: CSV means Comma-Separated Values, a plain-text way to store rows and columns.

questions.prompt: What do you call a collection of related data used for analysis (or to train a model)?
questions.explanation: A dataset is a collection of data points you can analyze or use for training/testing.

questions.prompt: In AI, what do we call the step where a trained model uses what it learned to make a prediction?
questions.explanation: Inference is when the trained model produces an output (like a prediction or generated text).

questions.prompt: In AI chat tools, what do you call the text you type to ask the model to do something?
questions.explanation: Your prompt is the instruction or question you give the AI.
